awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Improving Information Retrieval by Analysis of Temporal Evidence in a Unified Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Information retrieval (IR) systems are inherently temporal. Documents change, indexes acquire new documents, and systems answer or "field" queries differently over time. The vision of this project is to capitalize on this temporality to improve the models used for predicting document relevance. The approach is based on a novel probabilistic framework to allow temporal factors to improve IR effectiveness.  The framework situates temporality as a key factor in predicting the document relevance.  Initial work focuses on established text retrieval settings, estimating document relevance to keyword queries.  However, emerging domains such as social media and volunteer-maintained knowledge bases have an inherent temporality that demands new models.  Thus, during the project, research pursues problems of filtering and topic evolution.  Methods developed in this project will be experimentally evaluated using standard datasets. The project's expected outcome includes improved models and algorithms for retrieving, filtering, and organizing textual data that arrives incrementally over time. 

The project will benefit society in two ways. IR systems play a key role in people?s daily information use.  This project will advance the public's ability to negotiate an increasingly complex information landscape, because the expected outcomes will improve search engine technology.  Research results will be disseminated primarily via academic conferences and journals.  Work will also be stored in an archival institutional repository, affording the public long-term access to results.  Progress and general information about the project will be published on the project Web site (http://timer.lis.illinois.edu).  The project will provide research experience for students and will advance scientific education. In addition, course materials will be developed to support on-line teaching of information retrieval to non-technical students.

por.por_cntn:
Information retrieval (IR) systems are key tools for managing the huge amount of data that is available to people today. Assuring successful search engine performance is thus a high scientific and social priority. This project analyzed information retrieval as an inherently temporal phenomenon. By identifying temporal evidence, and by integrating it into a formal probabilistic model, the project advanced the state of the art in IR effectiveness.

Prior to the work entailed by this project, temporal factors had informed IR research only sporadically.  However, by the project's end in 2016, temporality has gained a formidable place in the attention of IR researchers.  This change was due in part to the activities of this project itself, as well as in recognition of the fact that domains such as social media and electronic publishing have pushed temporality to the fore of how, in many cases, people interact with text.

The vision of this project was to capitalize on temporality to help systems induce more nuanced, more realistic models for predicting relevance. During its lifespan, the project yielded a coherent theory for understanding time’s role in IR, allowing the PI and other scholars to improve the systems that help the public during research, learning, and everyday problem solving. The project introduced novel probabilistic models that cast the relationship between word-based and temporal evidence in IR in a multifaceted light. Besides these models themselves, the outcome of the project is comparative, weighing the merits and showing fundamental similarities among ways of accounting for time in IR.  This knowledge improves search system effectiveness.

In particular, the project led the PI and his colleagues to introduce time into IR as a form of pseudo-relevance feedback.  Resting on a novel theory, "the temporal cluster hypothesis," this project showed that a log-linear combination of temporal and lexical evidence--similar to log-linear models found in the Markov random field family of retrieval models--yielded consistently strong retrieval effectiveness.

This project benefits society in two ways. First, IR systems play a key role in people’s daily information use. Search engines help people find and synthesize the information that they rely on to make decisions, to learn, and to plan their daily affairs. Insofar as its results have shown improvements search engine technology, this project advanced the public’s ability to negotiate an increasingly complex information landscape. Second, the project advanced scientific education. The PI and his students produced a library of course-related software (available at https://github.com/uiucGSLIS) that supports teaching information retrieval to non-technical students. The project’s curricular goal was to improve the scientific fluency of library and information science (LIS) students by immersing them in the rigorous study of IR. Because most LIS students lack a scientific background, this work advanced the NSF’s mission of expanding science education.
